source.8d53650a:
from datetime import datetime

# Change T to " "
dates = [date.replace("T", " ") for date in data['Last Visited']]
dates = [datetime.fromisoformat(date) for date in dates]
data['Last Visited'] = dates
print("The type for the Last Visited Attribute is: " + str(type(dates[0])))
source.577e36a2:
min_date = min(data['Last Visited'])
max_date = max(data['Last Visited'])

date_range = max_date - min_date
print("Last Visited Range is: " + str(date_range))
source.9e3ed683:

data['Last Visited'] = new_dates

source.bbc68682:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Nike products count
nike_products = [p for p in data['Brand'] if "nike" in p.lower()]
num_nike = len(nike_products)

# Adidas products count
adidas_products = [p for p in data['Brand'] if "adidas" in p.lower()]
num_adidas = len(adidas_products)

# Customise plots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1,2, figsize=(10,5))
fig.suptitle("Number of Products by Adidas and Nike",fontsize=20)
y = [num_nike, num_adidas]
colors=['grey','silver']

# Bar chart
ax1.bar(x=['Nike','Adidas'], height=y, color=colors)
ax1.set_title("Number of Products by Brand")
ax1.set_xlabel("Brand")
ax1.text(x=-0.07, y=390,s=num_nike, fontsize=14)
ax1.text(x=0.88, y=1140,s=num_adidas, fontsize=14)
ax1.set_ylabel("Number of Products")

# Pie Chart
ax2.set_title("Proportion of Products by Brand")
ax2.pie(labels=['Nike','Adidas'], x=y, autopct='%.2f%%', colors=colors )
fig.tight_layout(pad=3.0)

nike_brand = data[data['Brand'] == "Nike"]

source.28314da5:
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from collections import Counter

plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))

nike_counter = Counter(nike_brand['Last Visited'])
nike_time_df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(nike_counter, orient='index', columns=['count'])

adidas_counter = Counter(adidas_brand['Last Visited'])
adidas_time_df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(adidas_counter, orient='index', columns=['count'])

sns.set_style("whitegrid")
sns.lineplot(y="count", x=nike_time_df.index, data=nike_time_df, label="Nike", color="silver")
plt.ylim(0,800)
plt.xlabel("Minute")
plt.title("Product Visits per Minute for Nike and Adidas")
sns.lineplot(y="count", x=adidas_time_df.index, data=adidas_time_df, label="Adidas")

source.4f278138: Since the average discount is 0%, this can indicate that Nike's products rarely go on sale. The listing price averages around $4452.30
source.ef96d607:
When comparing the number of products, Adidas has a lot more that Nike. Additionally, Adidas is categorized in 3 brands: Adidas CORE/NEO, Adidas SPORT PERFORMANCE and Adidas ORIGINALS, while Nike just has the one brand.

Furthermore, overall ratings and reviews are higher for Adidas than Nike with this dataset. The visits for Adidas's products are much higher than Nike's and seems to be in a much smaller time-span. Whilst both have products with the max-ratings of 5 stars, Nike has more 5 star rating across their products while Adidas has much more 5 star reviews per product.
Perhaps this can be indicative of Adidas's huge popularity with particular pieces while Nike has a nicer overall range of products.
source.b98fecfe:
Adidas

From the .describe() function, we can see that for Ratings, standard deviation is again, small at 1.14 and mean is 3.38. This is much higher than Nike's products which shows better satisfaction.

The Reviews standard deviation is even larger than Nike's, at a value of 28.04. Note that Adidas has a wider product range than Nike so number of reviews will fluctuate more due to more products. Despite this fluctuation, mean is 60.68, much greater than Nike's 8.36. It appears more people rate Adidas's products than Nike.
source.da72fa92: 1. Summarise Data
source.3fa0b51c: The data is fairly clean with the exception of 3 products with missing descriptions. We will change these null values to empty strings.
source.e14ef237:
4. Remove Duplicates

The dataset appears to have 7 exact duplicates of products. This may be an artifact from the data collection step. We will remove these.
source.2a115a17:
4. How often are people visiting these products?

Is there a trend in the date and time these products were last visited? We will arrange the Last Visited from oldest the newest and count how many records are in each minute time-slot for both Adidas and Nike.
source.45f784fb:
Nike

Nike has 120 products which have a Rating of 5 stars.
source.8d64bbed:
Nike

From the .describe() function, we can see that for Ratings, standard deviation is quite small, 2.08 and mean is 2.94. This is a poor satisfaction rating for their customers.

For the Reviews, the standard deviation is very large, at a value of 18.56. This is because products may be extremely popular, or new which drastically affects the number of people reviewing them. The mean is 8.36 but this number may not be reliable.
source.e095027e: There are redundacies with the Date as the difference between the oldest and newest Last Visited is only half an hour. Therefore, we shall only look at the minutes and seconds of the visits.
source.85412107: Adidas's products have a much larger discount percentage than Nike's (33.21% vs 0.00%). However, it should be noted that they have more products AND their listing prices, $8038.54, are much higher. Generally, if the goods are expensive, then it is more likely to be discounted.
source.8e20d6dd: Interestingly, despite a lower over-all rating for Nike's products (2.94), they have more 5 star rated items than Adidas's. But Adidas is more consistent with their products with many posessing 90+ reviews.

source.dcb01d2f:
2. Which brand is discounting more?

source.a9738ef3:
1. How many products per brand?

Since this data set is focused on Adidas and Nike, we will use these keywords to filter on the Brand attribute.
source.4e794d1f:
There are 3268 products, each having 10 attributes which are:

  1. Product Name
  2. Product ID
  3. Listing Price
  4. Sale Price
  5. Discount
  6. Brand
  7. Description
  8. Rating
  9. Reviews
  10. Last Visited
source.e5580d6a: There are more visits for Adidas in a shorter time frame than Nike. Numbers peak to more than 700 within 5 minutes while Nike fluctuates about 50 visits across 20 minutes. This doesn't tell us much about the products but the spikes from Adidas can be indicative of their many products available.
source.c09c9af1: It can be seen that there is a much higher distribution of products belonging to Adidas. One of the reasons why is that Adidas has a large proportion of sub-brands or collaborations while Nike falls under the one brand.

source.08406a41: By obtaining maximum Reviews after getting the top rated products, Men's Adidas Toe Side II Slippers and Men's Adidas Running Asweego Shoes are the most popular with the highest reviews of 99 and a max rating of 5 stars.

source.fc439255:
4) Summary 📝

This data set compares Adidas and Nike products, however, it isn't indicative of the performance of companies. Several data cleaning processes were used including:

  1. Changing the dates
  2. Removing duplicates
  3. Removing redundant information
  4. Changing null values to empty strings
source.a4fe03ca:
3. Remove Redundancies

It has been found that there is a redundant brand called "Adidas Adidas ORIGINALS" with 1 product in it. There is already a brand called "Adidas Originals" with several products in it. Therefore, we should be change this brand to belong to "Adidas ORIGINALS".
source.706fa958: There's a lot of products which have the same product name, 1730 to be exact. However, only 130 of these duplicates have the same reviews and ratings. Because these products have different reviews and ratings, we shall keep the latest occurrence based on highest reviews (we can't decrease reviews over time!).
source.47f33201: This is an exploratory notebook looking at the performances of each brand, what products are popular and how often people visit the website.
